G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 231, §1, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the District Court and the cause of action arises under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a71.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 231, §1, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the District Court and the cause of action arises under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a72.proposition: Venue is proper in Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §2, because the property that is the subject of this action is located in Somerville, and Defendant conducts business there.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, §14, a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment” of the leased premises.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 95 (1982.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential tenancy in Massachusetts.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 95 (1982.support_reasoning: The court expressly states, in its discussion of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common-law background, that every tenancy entails an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. It frames this as a general principle of Massachusetts landlord-tenant law, not limited to commercial leases, and the case itself concerns a residential tenancy. Thus, the opinion directly supports the proposition that the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential tenancy in Massachusetts.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 95 (1982.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.  Id.” (citing Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977)).

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718.proposition: The covenant protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with the use and enjoyment of the premises by acts or omissions of the landlord or those for whom the landlord is responsible.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718.support_reasoning: The court expressly describes the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment as being violated by substantial interference with the tenants’ use and enjoyment of their apartments caused by noise from a lounge operated by another tenant, where that interference was the natural and probable consequence of what the landlords did, failed to do, or permitted. It further holds that the landlords can be liable even without intent, so long as the disturbance is within their control and results from acts or omissions of parties for whom they are responsible. This aligns closely with the proposition stated.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent….”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s failure to take reasonable steps to prevent or remedy ongoing disturbances caused by other tenants under the same landlord’s control constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court explicitly analyzes the covenant of quiet enjoyment and holds that a landlord may be liable where, after notice that third-party misconduct in common areas seriously interferes with tenants’ use, the landlord fails to take reasonable steps within its control. The opinion states that if the housing authority “failed to take any action or inadequate action” to remove unlawful actors from property it owns and controls, thereby substantially interfering with tenants’ tenancies, it breaches the covenant. This squarely supports the proposition that failure to take reasonable steps to prevent or remedy ongoing disturbances by persons under the landlord’s control (here, on premises it controls) constitutes a breach.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Trustees of 226 South St. Condo. Trust v.raw_text: Trustees of 226 South St. Condo. Trust v. Richardson, 470 Mass. 491, 497 (2015)
Trustees of 226 South St. Condo. Trust v.proposition: The landlord’s duty includes responding effectively when one tenant’s behavior substantially interferes with another’s use of the premises.
Trustees of 226 South St. Condo. Trust v.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns public and press access to the names of jurors and the treatment of juror lists as judicial records. It does not address landlord-tenant law, duties of landlords, or interference by one tenant with another’s use of premises. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about a landlord’s duty to respond to tenant-on-tenant interference.
Trustees of 226 South St. Condo. Trust v.relevant_excerpt: For the reasons more fully set forth herein, we conclude that the public’s long-term interest in maintaining an open judicial process, as embodied in the United States Constitution and Massachusetts common law, requires that a list identifying the names of jurors who have been empanelled and rendered a verdict in a criminal case be retained in the court file of the case and be made available to the public in the same manner as other court records.

Winthrop M. Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass..raw_text: Winthrop M. Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 180, 184 (1990)
Winthrop M. Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass..proposition: Such interference constitutes a breach under G.L. c. 186, §14, as interpreted in Winthrop M. Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 180, 184 (1990); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997);Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708, 720 (2002); and Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872 (1991).
Winthrop M. Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns interference constituting a breach under G.L. c. 186, § 14 (a Massachusetts landlord-tenant statute). Winthrop M. Corp. v. Lowenthal is a contract/arbitration and attorney’s fees case; it does not involve landlord-tenant relations, G.L. c. 186, § 14, or any concept of interference under that statute. It therefore does not provide authority for the claimed proposition and is being cited outside its subject matter context.
Winthrop M. Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We emphasize that we are concerned in this case with a provision in a contract where the parties agreed to shift payment of legal fees to the losing party. The decisions involving statutes that call for the shifting of payment of legal fees to the losing party are not applicable. In those decisions, the legislative policies involved in the enactment of the statutes are of major importance, and those policies are not present where parties voluntarily agree to shift the payment.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.proposition: Such interference constitutes a breach under G.L. c. 186, §14, as interpreted in Winthrop M. Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 180, 184 (1990); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997);Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708, 720 (2002); and Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872 (1991).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.support_reasoning: Al‑Ziab addresses what level of landlord fault is required for a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 in the context of lead paint, and holds that strict statutory liability under the lead paint law, standing alone, is not a breach of § 14. It does not say that any given ‘interference’ constitutes a breach; instead, it clarifies that at least negligent conduct with notice or reason to know of the condition is required. Thus, using Al‑Ziab as authority that such interference (without clarifying fault/notice) constitutes a breach overstates the case’s holding.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Such interference constitutes a breach under G.L. c. 186, §14, as interpreted in Winthrop M. Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 180, 184 (1990); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997);Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708, 720 (2002); and Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872 (1991).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The proposition is that certain landlord interference constitutes a breach under G.L. c. 186, § 14. In Lowery, the Appeals Court expressly holds that the landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season both constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and violates G.L. c. 186, § 14, entitling the tenant to statutory remedies. This directly supports using Lowery as authority that such interference (failure to furnish heat) is a breach under § 14.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… As suggested by the language of the statute itself… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’… On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14… and (c) an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14.”

Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..raw_text: Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708, 720 (2002)
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..proposition: Such interference constitutes a breach under G.L. c. 186, §14, as interpreted in Winthrop M. Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 180, 184 (1990); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997);Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708, 720 (2002); and Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872 (1991).
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition is about interference constituting a breach under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but this opinion does not interpret or apply § 14 at all. Wesson concerns common-law constructive eviction and, more centrally, the adoption of mutually dependent covenants in commercial leases, allowing a tenant to terminate a lease and recover relocation costs when deprived of a substantial benefit. Because the decision neither cites nor discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14, it does not support the statutory proposition for which it is cited.
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We next consider whether the landlord’s actions regarding the leaky roof constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment amounting to the constructive eviction of the tenant. Where there is a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, the tenant may raise constructive eviction as a defense to an action to recover rent.… [W]e adopt the rule of mutually dependent covenants for commercial leases and conclude that the plaintiff landlord breached his covenant to maintain the roof…”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872 (.proposition: Such interference constitutes a breach under G.L. c. 186, §14, as interpreted in Winthrop M. Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 180, 184 (1990); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997);Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708, 720 (2002); and Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872 (1991).
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872 (.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns interference as a breach under G.L. c. 186, §14 (the covenant of quiet enjoyment). In this excerpt, the court notes that the tenant asserted a §14 counterclaim and that the judge found for her, but the Supreme Judicial Court does not analyze §14 liability or define what constitutes interference or breach under that statute. The opinion instead focuses on recusal, Chapter 93A emotional distress damages, and warranty of habitability damages, so it does not provide substantive authority for the specific §14 proposition cited.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872 (.relevant_excerpt: "After her landlord, the plaintiff Nick Haddad, commenced a summary process action... the defendant, Luz Gonzalez, filed six counterclaims alleging: (1) breach of the implied warranty of habitability; (2) breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L.c. 186, § 14 (1990 ed.); ... After a trial, a judge of the Housing Court found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims.... We now affirm."
